headline: Treasury Auctions
summary: The Treasury will auction $60 billion in reopened debt from notes originally issued over the summer.

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Navigating Windows 8
summary: Explore changes in Microsoft's new Windows 8 operating system.

headline: Questions Around Crowdfunding
summary: Crowdfunding may turn out to be a headache for the brokerage business.

headline: Designing Woman
summary: The groundbreaking works of Jeanne Gang

headline: Seoul Fashion Week in Pictures
summary: Looks from An Yoon Jung, Choi Ji Hyung and more from Seoul Fashion Week.

headline: Yuan Hits Daily Upper Limit Again
summary: China's yuan hits the upper limit of its daily trading band against the U.S. dollar for the second straight day amid global demand for emerging market assets and renewed optimism about the Chinese economy.

headline: Sabathia Has Surgery to Fix Bone Spur
summary: Yankee ace CC Sabathia underwent arthroscopic surgery on his pitching elbow Thursday to shave down a bone spur that caused him pain this season, the team announced.

headline: 'Frankenstorm' Headed to Region
summary: Greater New York began preparing for Hurricane Sandy as an unusual confluence of weather patterns started taking shape that could produce what meteorologists dubbed a "Frankenstorm."

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Oct. 26, 2012

headline: Bushwick Eateries Boost Variety on Menu
summary: Bushwick recently has seen a flurry of venues either opening or announcing their imminent arrival, all bringing new cultural sensibilities to the neighborhood.

headline: Second Arrest in Shooting of Police Officer, Motorist
summary: A second person was arrested in connection with the shooting deaths of a Long Island police officer and an innocent motorist. The Queens District Attorney's office said police found the suspect with a handgun that may be the murder weapon.

headline: South Korea GDP Growth Slows
summary: The South Korean economy grew at the slowest pace in nearly three years in the third quarter from the prior three months, adding to pressure on the central bank to keep its policy rate low to promote growth.

headline: New York Cop Accused in Plot to Kill and Eat Women
summary: A New York City police officer was accused Thursday of plotting with others for months to kidnap women, kill and eat them.

headline: Libor Probe Spreads to 9 More Banks
summary: Nine more banks have received subpoenas in connection with a probe into alleged widespread interest-rate manipulation by banks.

headline: Macquarie Profit Gains on Trading Income
summary: Macquarie Group said first-half profit climbed 18% from a year earlier on strong income from its trading and funds businesses, and reiterated hopes for an improved full-year result if market conditions didn't worsen.

headline: Sorry, Carmelo, It's All on You
summary: With Stoudemire injured, the Knicks will need Anthony to do the bulk of the scoring—whether he likes it or not.

headline: Bo Trial Unlikely Before Meeting
summary: Former Communist Party star Bo Xilai was expelled from the nation's rubber-stamp parliament, state media reported on Friday, stripping him of his legal immunity and setting the stage for his trial on a number of alleged offenses.

headline: Iranian Aid Programs in Afghanistan Expand Influence
summary: Iran is funding aid projects and expanding intelligence networks across Afghanistan, moving to fill the void to be left by the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan by the end of 2014, according to U.S. and Afghan officials.

headline: Middle Class Looks For Answers
summary: Conversations along Floral Avenue in Norwood, Ohio, suggest many voters fear neither President Barack Obama or Republican challenger Mitt Romney can end their worries over growing health-care costs, stagnant incomes and the feeble job market.

headline: The Man With a Million Acres
summary: Reclusive billionaire Brad Kelley is hardly ever photographed. He doesn't use email. And he owns more land than the state of Rhode Island.

headline: The Rebirth of a Rock Opera
summary: "Jesus Christ Superstar" is mounted as Andrew Lloyd Webber always intended: in concert.

headline: China's Staid Yuan Roams
summary: The once-predictable Chinese currency has become increasingly volatile, which signals a stronger role for markets in the yuan's moves but poses foreign-exchange risks for businesses and investors.

headline: Laos Comes of Age as Trading Partner
summary: A vote on Friday that formally approved Laos's application to join the World Trade Organization marked a key coming of age for the small, landlocked Communist country.

headline: Movement on Tappan Zee Bridge
summary: The Cuomo administration has winnowed its search for the builder of a new Tappan Zee Bridge to a single team of bidders.

headline: Emails Offer Murky Picture on Dalli's Exit
summary: John Dalli, the EU's health commissioner who resigned last week, reiterated that he may have been the victim of entrapment by the tobacco industry in a cash-for-influence probe, but emails seen by The Wall Street Journal raise questions about that argument.

headline: 4 Generations of 5-String Trailblazers
summary: When most New Yorkers think of the banjo they think of the movie "Deliverance" or "The Beverly Hillbillies." But a traveling band of banjo masters is making its way east to usher in a new era for the instrument and highlight its long relationship with New York.

headline: Wine Wordsmith
summary: If readers were asked to name the world's most popular wine writer, odds are they might be stumped for a name. According to the biographical note on the dust jacket of the 37th edition of "Hugh Johnson's Pocket Wine Book," that writer is Mr. Johnson himself.

headline: Nintendo Slashes Profit Outlook
summary: Nintendo slashed its fiscal-year profit outlook by 70%, weighed down by weaker-than-expected demand for its 3DS hand-held game machine, the strong yen and manufacturing costs.

headline: A 'Public' Discourse With Oskar Eustis
summary: We chat with the artistic director of the Public Theater about a new season of shows, his role in their development, and the decision to invite Mike Daisey back to perform.

headline: Asia in Pictures
summary: A paramilitary guard stands before the bars of a main gate to the No.1 Detention Center in Beijing, Ai Weiwei dances in a 'Gangnam Style' music video cover, a woman uses a ticket vending machine as soldiers took part in an anti-terror and security drill in Seoul, and more.

headline: The Jazz Scene: Dressing Up to Get Down
summary: This week's Jazz Scene calendar swings with the John Coltrane Festival at Lincoln Center, then dresses up for some Halloween-week parties at Hudson Studios and the Red Lotus Room in Brooklyn.

headline: 'X-Files' Star's Sri Lanka Home
summary: Gillian Anderson, who played Dana Scully on 'The X-Files,' restored this Sri Lankan property. With 40-foot ceilings, it was originally built big enough to accommodate an elephant.

headline: DioGuardi of 'American Idol' Relists Her L.A. Home
summary: Former "American Idol" judge Kara DioGuardi relists in Studio City, Calif., for $7 million; a Washington home that has belonged to a Vanderbilt and a Roosevelt asks $5 million; a Montecito, Calif., ranch once on the market for $25 million heads to a no-minimum auction.

headline: Wal-Mart to Open 100 Stores in China
summary: Wal-Mart plans to open 100 stores in the next three years in China, marking a slowdown from its earlier growth rates in the increasing competitive retail landscape there.

headline: Corn Prices Sink as Exports Slack
summary: Corn futures fell 1.7% amid renewed concerns about tepid export demand for the U.S. crop.

headline: Credit Suisse Seeks to Run Bourse
summary: Credit Suisse is quietly pushing to turn one of its trading venues into an exchange, an unusual bid that, if successful, would create the only U.S. stock exchange owned outright by a Wall Street bank.

headline: Years of Working for Womens' Rights
summary: Actors Tina Fey, Stanley Tucci and Janeane Garofalo and New York Congressman Jerrold Nadler and Attorney General Eric Schneiderman, among 650 other socialites, gathered to celebrate 20 years of the Center for Reproductive Rights' work.

headline: Samsung's Profit Jumps 91%
summary: Samsung's third-quarter profit jumped 91% in a period when it was the only big manufacturer with new phones at the high end of the market.

headline: iPhone Shines but iPad Dims
summary: Apple regained some momentum in its fourth quarter, selling more iPhones than expected while triggering some concerns about the iPad.

headline: Romney's Team Makes Push in Ohio
summary: Mitt Romney is making a full-court press to win Ohio, taking a page from the playbook of George W. Bush in 2004, when a big factor was raw turnout and enthusiasm among the Buckeye State's rural areas and social conservatives.

headline: 'The Glass Ceiling of On-Air Drinking'
summary: End-of-the-week notes from a week of party reporting.

headline: Big Bashes, Intimate Affairs
summary: Maybe it's economic optimism, maybe it's just a busy time of year, but people are throwing really large parties these days. They're overflowing with people, though maybe not as many hors d'oeuvres.

headline: Private Properties
summary: Former 'American Idol' judge and songwriter Kara DioGuardi has relisted her Studio City, Calif., home for $7 million; a Montecito, Calif., ranch previously on the market for $25 million will be auctioned off next month; and a Washington, D.C., home has gone on the market asking $5 million.

headline: Name That Teen Type
summary: Josh Schwartz, the television producer behind NBC's "Chuck" and CW's "Gossip Girl," knows his way around a coming-of-age story. A look at some of the archetypal teen characters from his work.

headline: Warner Bros. to Hold Movies From Redbox for 28 Days

headline: Book Rivals Explore Deal
summary: Pearson said talks are under way to combine its Penguin Group with Random House, which is owned by Bertelsmann.

headline: Energy Market Shifts Ahead of Swaps Regulatory Overhaul
summary: Energy companies and other firms are switching out of trading derivatives known as swaps, which have been targeted by regulators, and moving into similar futures contracts.

headline: Asian Firms Brace for Profit Pain
summary: Asia's biggest companies are predicting profit pain as sluggish growth grinds on in China and Europe.

headline: Durable-Goods Orders Rise
summary: Durable-goods orders posted the largest gain in more than 2½ years in September as demand for aircraft and defense products rebounded. Weekly jobless claims, meanwhile, fell by 23,000 last week to 369,000.

headline: Return to Fray Is Uneasy For Former Governor
summary: Republican Tommy Thompson, who was governor of Wisconsin for 14 years, has returned to the state and is waging a tougher-than-expected fight for a U.S. Senate seat against Democratic Rep. Tammy Baldwin.

headline: Ex-Galleon Employee Avoids Prison
summary: A former Galleon Group employee whose cooperation helped expose insider trading at the hedge-fund firm was sentenced to three years' probation after winning praise from the government for his cooperation in its investigation.

headline: Playing Hardball With China Investors
summary: John Bussey asks should the U.S. block investment by Chinese companies until China opens its market wider to U.S. business?

headline: Selling a Piece of Old Japan, to Save It
summary: The market for Tokyo's historic homes is fueled by overseas buyers.

headline: Telefónica Shores Up Its 'Firewall'
summary: Telefonica, one of the world's most indebted companies, could establish two units—one in Latin America and one in Europe—to steer clear of any further worsening of Spain's economic troubles.

headline: High Costs Bedevil Builders
summary: New-home construction has picked up momentum in recent months after years of contraction. But the industry is facing a fresh challenge: building costs are going through the roof.

headline: Amazon Posts Loss
summary: Amazon swung to a third-quarter loss as stronger revenue was masked again by aggressive spending to spur growth.

headline: U.K. Posts Surprise 1% Growth
summary: The U.K. emerged from its longest double-dip recession since World War II, data showed, but one-off factors such as the London Olympics may mask deep-rooted problems and economists expect growth to be weak for some time to come.

headline: Still Very Much Above Ground

headline: Using Cheery Hues to Paint War Scenes
summary: At his first museum solo show at the Wadsworth in Hartford, Conn., Baghdad-born Ahmed Alsoudani brings a colorful approach to difficult subjects.

headline: Models, Bigwigs, Rockers: All Aboard at St. Pancras Chambers
summary: The Victorian-era landmark St. Pancras Chambers draws professionals seeking to ride the transformation of a London district.

headline: Spirit AeroSystems Takes Hit
summary: Spirit AeroSystem, one of Boeing's largest suppliers, said unexpected trouble cutting costs caused it to take a $590 million charge on work it does on several of the world's newest civilian aircraft. Its stock fell 30% Thursday.

headline: When No Detail Is Too Small
summary: Behind the scenes as the American Museum of Natural History adds some scatological realism to a renovated diorama.

headline: Fire the Manager! Really?
summary: Does changing the man at the top really have a beneficial effect on struggling teams?

headline: China Court to Weigh Corporate-Spy Case
summary: A fight over alleged corporate espionage goes before China's highest court Friday, in a test case watched by U.S. companies for signs of whether China is willing to rein in what they see as unfair behavior.

headline: California Colleges' Funding Hangs on a Ballot Measure
summary: California's public universities are getting ready to raise tuition and cut staff, while students are bracing for the potential impact on their schooling, should voters reject a tax increase on November's ballot.

summary: Great works of art can profit from radical reinterpretations that fling conventional wisdom out the window. Playwrights and their posthumous representatives should lighten up and let directors do their damnedest.

headline: A Tragedy of Irish Proportions
summary: Brian Friel's "The Freedom of the City" is a meditation on how politics can crush innocent people in the pincers of absurdity.

headline: DreamWorks Chairman Resigns
summary: The chairman of DreamWorks Animation SKG resigned, after having served in that position since the studio became a public company in 2004.

headline: Stern Gets Ready for the Buzzer
summary: Is David Stern indeed the BOAT? The case can be made; it's been made repeatedly during Stern's tenure, in which the powerful commissioner seemed to loom as an Oz behind the backboards.

headline: Bonus Season Could Be a Bummer
summary: One in five Wall Street bankers and traders won't get a bonus for 2012, according to a closely watched study to be released next week.

headline: Insect Whittles Down Timber Supply

headline: Apple Needs a Big Holiday

headline: Women's PACs See Surge In Giving
summary: Issues such as abortion and contraception in the election has been an unexpected boon for pro-Democratic women's advocacy groups, and it is also helping antiabortion organizations, though on a smaller scale.

headline: How the Noble Have Fallen

headline: Windows Launch Brings Out True Fans

headline: State of Dysfunction

headline: Amazon Fails to Deliver Top Line
summary: After years of focusing on Amazon.com's expenses, there may be reason for investors to worry about its revenues.

headline: Getting a Six-Touchdown Head Start

headline: It's Cooler Runnings for Lolo Jones
summary: It isn't too soon to start looking ahead to the 2014 Sochi Games—at least that's what Lolo Jones is doing.

headline: The Labor-Intensive Life
summary: "Call the Midwife" is a series so persuasively achieved that it's hard not to see why it won higher ratings during its British run than even the beloved "Downton Abbey."

summary: Religious organizations, real estate agents, operas and other interest groups are mobilizing to preserve their tax breaks as political momentum grows for limiting them.

summary: Apax Partners and Apollo Global Management have emerged as the leading contenders for McGraw-Hill Education.

headline: Bradley Smith: The Dangers of an Informed Electorate

headline: David Aikman: America's Religious Past Fades in a Secular Age
summary: Unthinkable to the Founders: One in five Americans today has no religious affiliation.

headline: Joe Lieberman: My Line on Defense—No More Cuts
summary: When Congress meets after the election, it should reduce the debt without taking a dollar more from the military.

summary: About half the entrepreneurs in a recent survey said policies aimed at giving small businesses access to capital are "critical." Lending to small firms has remained sluggish despite government efforts to kick-start it.

summary: Why the cure for an economic or social problem may be worse than the disease it purports to fix.

headline: CFTC Poised to Rein In Swaps Trade
summary: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission is poised to propose a sweeping set of postcrisis rules for derivatives trading that could mark a major setback for big players in the multitrillion-dollar industry.

headline: Don't Be Obtuse
summary: Geometric accessories in slick color-blocking add a sharp degree of polish to any outfit.

summary: The new anthology, "Totally MAD: 60 Years of Humor, Satire, Stupidity and Stupidity," accentuates how the magazine has spawned a prodigious book-publishing operation, with close to 300 MAD titles.

headline: Behind Sweden's Grisliest Serial Killer
summary: A book detailing the story of Thomas Quick, a confessed multiple murderer who may have committed no murders at all, has riveted Sweden.

summary: Results from the latest Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist Poll surveys show that both candidates still have a path to victory in the Electoral College that runs through the West.

headline: Don't Judge That Book by Its Cover...
summary: It's not uncommon that book covers resemble one another, but several new entries may have readers doing a double take.

headline: Renovating a Home While Rebuilding a Life

headline: Rajaratnam Appeal Targets Wiretaps
summary: Lawyers for the Galleon Group chief said wiretaps should have been kept out of evidence because prosecutors failed to mention an SEC investigation.

summary: The U.S. oil industry says it is spending 'tens of millions of dollars' to persuade its employees and others to support and promote oil-friendly candidates this November.

headline: A Diva's Desert Hideaway
summary: Two peripatetic opera singers craft a retreat with vast views, glass walls and, of course, great acoustics on the outskirts of Santa Fe, N.M.

headline: South Africa's Gordhan Vows Fiscal Discipline
summary: South Africa's finance minister pledged to keep a lid on the budget while shifting spending from wages toward infrastructure.

headline: China Reaches Accord on Military Makeup
summary: China promoted four more Chinese generals to key military posts, indicating its leadership had almost completed a generational shake-up of the military top brass.

headline: Accounts Clash on Role of Egypt Shootout Victim

headline: A Diva's Desert Hideaway
summary: Two peripatetic opera singers craft a retreat with vast views, glass wallsand, of course, great acoustics on the outskirts of Santa Fe.

headline: Gun-Sales Restriction Is Upheld for People Under 21
summary: People under the age of 21 can't buy handguns from dealers, an appeals court ruled, upholding a federal law and rejecting a challenge from the National Rifle Association.

headline: Ford Cuts Deep in Europe
summary: Ford outlined a broad plan to stem steep losses in Europe by closing three auto and parts factories, cutting 13% of its workforce and 18% of its new-car production capacity in the region.

headline: Wood That's Tough as Nails
summary: What natural building material is highly durable, resists flames and doesn't float? It's ipe wood, a material that upscale builders and interior designers are increasingly incorporating into their plans. But density comes at a price.

headline: U.S. Economy Is in the Eye of the Beholder
summary: Four years after having their "Minsky moment," economists' term for when good assets are dumped in a financial panic, Americans are expressing an altogether different sentiment. Call it an Alfred E. Neuman interlude.

headline: Presidents at the Polls
summary: Presidential candidates are assured of at least one vote each election -- their own. Take a look back at candidates' trips to the voting booths.

headline: Stocks Lurch to Small Gains
summary: Blue chips ended the day higher after seesawing between gains and losses, as investors tried to decipher middling readings on companies and the U.S. economy.

headline: Court Upholds Ex-NBA Star's Win vs. Morgan Keegan
summary: A U.S. court of appeals upheld a $1.5 million arbitration panel ruling against Morgan Keegan & Co. for losses sustained by basketball star Horace Grant in its mortgage-backed bond funds.

headline: US Airways, AMR to Weigh Merger Benefits
summary: American Airlines, its creditors and US Airways officials are to meet on Tuesday to consider potential revenue increases and cost savings that could be achieved through a merger, an evaluation that could determine whether US Airways makes a formal offer.

headline: An Investment in Words
summary: Frenchman Gérard Lhéritier heads one of the largest private collections of rare letters and manuscripts.

headline: The Written Word
summary: Le Musée des Lettres et Manuscrits in Paris houses one of the largest private collections of rare letters and manuscripts in the world.

headline: Greece Faces Need for Additional Assistance
summary: Greece will need an extra $38.9 billion in aid from its international creditors through 2016 to make up for a deeper-than-expected recession and a two-year delay in budget targets, senior European finance-ministry officials were told Thursday.

headline: Tax Tips for the Next Two Months
summary: Some traditional year-end tax-saving techniques might not work this year—and could even backfire. Here's some advice from tax experts.

headline: Emerging-Market Currencies Recover Modestly
summary: Emerging-market currencies ended their week-long slide, strengthening across the board as investors took advantage of cheaper prices to enter the market.

headline: Going South for Winter
summary: Long a vacation destination for the smart Latin American crowd, the area around Punta del Este has become popular with many Americans and Europeans. For an even chicer party scene, venture north to Brazil's Florianópolis.

headline: Microsoft's Windows Test: Courting Consumers
summary: Microsoft spent billions of dollars and more than three years remodeling its flagship product. Now the hard work begins: Getting consumers, software developers and other allies excited about Windows software again.

headline: Treasurys Retreat for Second Day
summary: Treasurys fell for a second session on signs the U.S. economy continues to recover, leading to a mixed reception at the last of this week's government note sales.

headline: Money Funds Add $940 Million
summary: Assets in money-market funds rose by $940 million in the week ended Wednesday as gains to institutional nongovernment funds offset declines from other fund categories, according to the Investment Company Institute.

headline: Credit Suisse Heeds Market's Message
summary: Credit Suisse's efforts to change from a highly leveraged, boom-era investment bank into a postcrisis, client-driven, low-risk brokerage has been a painful process. But a better-than-expected underlying third-quarter net income suggests the worst may be over.

headline: The Beauty of the Roussillon
summary: Where are the world's most beautiful vineyards? In Europe, one region that stands out is the Roussillon in the northern foothills of the Pyrenees, home to France's most southern wineries.

headline: Simple Perfection
summary: In San Sebastian, where there are more Michelin stars per capita than anywhere else in the Western world, Ibai's simple dishes are a glimpse at Spanish gastronomy's future perfect.

headline: Lehigh Gas Partners Climbs in Debut
summary: Lehigh Gas Partners' units traded higher in their IPO, the latest high-yielding limited partnership to meet healthy investor demand.

headline: Sprint's Loss Widens
summary: Sprint's third-quarter loss widened on steep subscriber losses and the continuing shutdown of its older Nextel network.

headline: We Can't Know What the Future Will Bring
summary: Fall's mind-bending fashion considers the shape of things to come.

headline: Back to the Future
summary: Visions of our future, through the eyes of Comme des Garçons, Balenciaga, Prada, Versace and others.

headline: Canadian Dollar Gives Back Gains
summary: The Canadian dollar ceded earlier gains against its U.S. rival, in a market searching for direction.

headline: Nobel Folks Should Give Dylan a Chance
summary: Regarding Joseph Epstein's(op-ed, Oct. 15): I have been hoping that when the literature prize committee gets over its anti-Americanism, Bob Dylan and Philip Roth would get their chance.

headline: Paul G. Allen
summary: Microsoft cofounder and private space-travel advocate Paul G. Allen offers a few of his favorite things.

headline: Bringing Up the Books
summary: Hilary Mantel talks about winning the Man Booker Prize, tales of Tudor England and what's next for the English author.

headline: New York Times Profit Sinks
summary: New York Times third-quarter earnings fell 85% as the media company's declining advertising revenue continued to outpace the growth of circulation revenue.

headline: Labor Costs Weigh on United Continental
summary: United Continental' reported a 99% slide in third-quarter profit, falling short of expectations as special labor and integration costs wiped out most of its earnings.

headline: Labeling GMO Products, and Others
summary: Regarding Alex Berezow's "Biotechnology on the Ballot" (op-ed, Oct. 18): Irrespective of all of the myriad benefits of genetically modified organism products, I still feel I have a right to know what I am eating. Attempts to maintain content secrecy just raises suspicions. Opponents of Prop. 37 are battling transparency.

headline: George McGovern Was a Prophet for Peace
summary: I am disturbed by your editorial "George McGovern" (Oct. 22) on the death of George McGovern. The best thing you could find to say about him is that later in life he learned about the burdens of government regulation of business.

headline: Driving Commodities Trading Away
summary: Regarding the Oct. 23 letter from Commodity Futures Trading Commission Commissioner Bart Chilton: Several years ago, when Congress began making noises about imposing controls on commodities futures trading, many traders moved from New York to markets in Zurich and in Amsterdam.

headline: Affirmative Action to End Race as Admission Criterion
summary: I was disappointed by the misleading analysis of statistics in Bill Woodson's letter ("Is Unraveling of Narrow Affirmative Action Premature?," Oct. 20). Mr. Woodson notes 60% of California's population is nonwhite and thereby concludes 26% minority representation in the University of California system is substantially inadequate.

headline: The Art of Calling In Sick—Or Not
summary: As flu season approaches, people soon will wake up to a tricky calculation: Should you drag yourself into work feeling awful? Or can you get away with staying home to heal?

headline: Brazil's Real Closes Nearly Unchanged
summary: Brazil's real finished nearly unchanged against the dollar even after the nation's central bank called a foreign-exchange reverse swap auction earlier in the session to roll over outstanding swap contracts. The reverse swap was the second this week.

headline: Single-Sex Schools: Vive la Différence or Oppression?
summary: The debate over single-sex schooling reminds us why bogus claims must be swiftly rebutted. In "A Right to Choose Single-Sex Education " (op-ed, Oct. 17) Sens. Kay Bailey Hutchison and Barbara Mikulski state that "some students learn better in a single-gender environment." So which students are these?

headline: American Art's Poet of Lonely Voyeurism
summary: "Edward Hopper" at the Grand Palais, the first major show in France for the 20th-century American artist, is a splendid retrospective that covers his entire career.

headline: What's On Around Europe
summary: The Weekend Journal's guide to the best exhibitions, concerts, theater, opera and events across Europe.

headline: Damned by Verse
summary: The National Theatre in London's modern-ish dress production of Tirso de Molina's "Damned by Despair" boasts ingenious sets and a terrific cast but its blank verse sounds wrong in the mouths of the mobsters.

headline: Dollar Advances on Yen
summary: The U.S. dollar rose to a four-month high against the yen as expectations grew that the Bank of Japan will take aggressive easing steps next week.
